thread.title_full: Dehradun-Mussoorie Highway: Dehradun-Mussoorie Highway Closure Due to Heavy Rain | Dehradun News - Times of India

author: Times Of India
title: Dehradun-Mussoorie Highway: Dehradun-Mussoorie Highway Closure Due to Heavy Rain | Dehradun News - Times of India
text: Dehradun/ Mussoorie: The Dehradun-Mussoorie highway remained closed for several hours on Wednesday night following heavy rain in the district that continued till Thursday morning. Since then, it has been closed for heavy traffic. Damage across Doon was extensive as several stretches of roads washed away in Chandrabani, Maldevta, and Patel Nagar areas, along with damage to city roads. Two roads were washed away in Saraswati Vihar area and several retaining walls collapsed. Tanmayee Tyagi & Anmol JainWe also published the following articles recentlyDoon-Mussoorie highway remains closed for several hours at night amid rainDehradun-Mussoorie highway remained shut for hours due to heavy rains, damaging roads and infrastructure across the district. Numerous reports of waterlogging, power outages, and landslides were received. The Mussoorie-Dehradun road saw a landslide, leading to restricted traffic. Authorities plan to install a Bailey bridge to manage heavy traffic soon, with repair work underway in affected areas.112204350Doon-Mussoorie highway remains closed for several hours at night amid rainHeavy rains led to the closure of the Dehradun-Mussoorie highway and extensive damage in Dehradun, with roads washed away and power outages reported. Landslides and sinking slopes further disrupted travel, affecting areas such as Tapovan, Raipur, and Mussoorie. Temporary measures were undertaken to mitigate the damage and restore the traffic flow.112204363Dehradun schools, Anganwadi centers to remain closed on Friday due to heavy rain alertThe district of Dehradun observed a closure of all schools and Anganwadi centers on July 26 due to an 'orange' alert for heavy rain. District Magistrate Sonika stated that both government and private institutions from class 1 to 12 were suspended to ensure safety as the region faced threats of landslides and severe weather conditions.112031492
